Package com.barryholroyd.evermore.mapitems

All MapItems are either Targets or Pins.

See: Description

  • Class Summary 
    Class Description
    MiTop  

Package com.barryholroyd.evermore.mapitems Description

All MapItems are either Targets or Pins. Users place Targets on the map and then generate collections of Pins around the Targets. MapItems are stored in the MapItemRegistry.

THE FOLLOWING IS BEING CONSIDERED FOR SUBSTANTIAL REFACTORING.
Storing the MapItems in a hierarchy is not always the best approach for accessing the MapItems -- sometimes searches have to be done which do not map well to the hierarchy. In addition, the dual hierarchy approach (designed to support inheritance and one to support the storage of MapItem instances) can be confusing. The MapItemRegistry was originally introduced to support searches which were non-hierarchical in nature and that eventually led to the removal of the orginal approach of storing the MapItemsin hashmaps within the individuial MiSubclass* instances. At this point, it is probably worth removing the instance hierarchy completely; it is also worth considering whether or not the inheritance hierarchy is worth the additional complexity it introduces or not.

There is a conceptual hierarchy for managing MapItems:

Top->Types->Classes->Subclasses

Each of these four object types, except Top, is an abstract class and has subclasses defined under it. 

 MiType
 MyTypeTargets: MapItem placed by the user on the map as the target location for a search.
 MyTypePins:    MapItem placed on the map as the result of a search.
 MiClass
 MiClassKeymarks:       Unique by EntityAdrsType, map presence stored across app instances.
 MiClassTargets:        Placed on map, minimal user interaction.
 MiClassContacts:       Contact-specific interactions.
 MiClassSearches:       Various types of Searches.
 MiSubclass
 MiSubclassTargetsManual
 MiSubclassTargetsSearch
 MiSubclassKeymarks
 MiSubclassContacts
 MiSubclassSearch1
 ...
 MiSubclassSearch7
A single instance of each of the classes in the four class hierarchies defined above is created at initialization and the instances are then linked together in a tree as follows. 
 Top
 Target         [ Type ]
 Target         [ Class ]
 TargetsManual  [ Subclass ]
 TargetsSearch  [ Subclass ]
 Pin            [ Type ]
 Keymark                [ Class ]
 Keymarks       [ Subclass ]
 Contact                [ Class ]
 Contacts       [ Subclass ]
 Search         [ Class ]
 Search1                [ Subclass ]
 Search2                [ Subclass ]
 ...

Barry Holroyd
